conclusion: There are objects above the slabs, illuminated by a light source, casting shadows A, B, and C on the ground.
The problem asks how A, B, and C will change in position and size when the light source moves to the right above the objects.

premise: Light rays now arrive from a different horizontal direction.
conclusion: A shadow is always cast on the side opposite the light, so when the lamp slides to the right every shadow slides to the left.

premise: The height of the lamp has not changed.
conclusion: The vertical angle of the rays (and therefore the overall length of each shadow measured away from its object) is almost unchanged; only the horizontal position and a small horizontal stretch change.
Shadow A corresponds to the bird-cage.

premise: The light source moves to the right.
conclusion: Shadow A shifts to the left of the cage instead of being nearly underneath it.

premise: The cage is tall and fairly symmetrical.
conclusion: The outline of shadow A stays much the same but becomes a little wider in the left-right direction.
Shadow B corresponds to the spinning-top or rod-like object.

premise: The light source moves to the right.
conclusion: Shadow B flips to the left of the object; the long thin streak that is now on the right rotates to the left.

premise: The object is tall and thin.
conclusion: Shadow B remains the longest of the three; its length may even increase slightly because the light is hitting it more sideways.

premise: The light source moves to the right.
conclusion: The orientation of shadow B changes: the 'pointer' that currently leans down-right will lean down-left after the move.
Shadow C corresponds to the drumstick.

premise: The light source moves to the right.
conclusion: Shadow C slides left, following the same rule as the other shadows.
Shadow C has almost the same overall footprint; only a slight horizontal stretching and leftward displacement are noticeable.
